trans-unit.source: Azure AD Cordova Getting Started | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Azure AD Cordova Getting Started | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: How to build a Cordova application that integrates with Azure AD for sign in and calls Azure AD protected APIs using OAuth.
trans-unit.target: How to build a Cordova application that integrates with Azure AD for sign in and calls Azure AD protected APIs using OAuth.

trans-unit.source: Integrate Azure AD with an Apache Cordova app
trans-unit.target: Integrate Azure AD with an Apache Cordova app

trans-unit.source: Apache Cordova makes it possible for you to develop HTML5/JavaScript applications which can run on mobile devices as full-fledged native applications.
trans-unit.target: Apache Cordova makes it possible for you to develop HTML5/JavaScript applications which can run on mobile devices as full-fledged native applications.

trans-unit.source: With Azure AD, you can add enterprise grade authentication capabilities to your Cordova applications.
trans-unit.target: With Azure AD, you can add enterprise grade authentication capabilities to your Cordova applications.

trans-unit.source: Thanks to a Cordova plugin wrapping Azure AD's native SDKs on iOS, Android, Windows Store and Windows Phone, you can enhance your application to support sign on with your users' AD accounts, gain access to Office 365 and Azure API, and even protect calls to your own custom Web API.
trans-unit.target: Thanks to a Cordova plugin wrapping Azure AD's native SDKs on iOS, Android, Windows Store and Windows Phone, you can enhance your application to support sign on with your users' AD accounts, gain access to Office 365 and Azure API, and even protect calls to your own custom Web API.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial we will use the Apache Cordova plugin for Active Directory Authentication Library (ADAL) to improve a simple app with the following features:
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial we will use the Apache Cordova plugin for Active Directory Authentication Library (ADAL) to improve a simple app with the following features:

trans-unit.source: With just few lines of code, authenticate an AD user and obtain a token for calling the Azure AD Graph API.
trans-unit.target: With just few lines of code, authenticate an AD user and obtain a token for calling the Azure AD Graph API.

trans-unit.source: Use that token to invoke the Graph API to query that directory and display the results
trans-unit.target: Use that token to invoke the Graph API to query that directory and display the results

trans-unit.source: Leverage the ADAL token cache for minimizing the authentication prompts for the user.
trans-unit.target: Leverage the ADAL token cache for minimizing the authentication prompts for the user.

trans-unit.source: In order to do this, you’ll need to:
trans-unit.target: In order to do this, you’ll need to:

trans-unit.source: Register an application with Azure AD
trans-unit.target: Register an application with Azure AD

trans-unit.source: Add code to your app to request tokens
trans-unit.target: Add code to your app to request tokens

trans-unit.source: Add code to use the token for querying the Graph API and display results.
trans-unit.target: Add code to use the token for querying the Graph API and display results.

trans-unit.source: Create the Cordova deployment project with all the platforms you want to target, and the Cordova ADAL plugin and test the solution in emulators.
trans-unit.target: Create the Cordova deployment project with all the platforms you want to target, and the Cordova ADAL plugin and test the solution in emulators.

trans-unit.source: 0. Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: 0. Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: To complete this tutorial you will need:
trans-unit.target: To complete this tutorial you will need:

trans-unit.source: An Azure AD tenant where you have an account with app development rights
trans-unit.target: An Azure AD tenant where you have an account with app development rights

trans-unit.source: A development environment configured to use Apache Cordova
trans-unit.target: A development environment configured to use Apache Cordova

trans-unit.source: If you have both already set up, please proceed directly to step 1.
trans-unit.target: If you have both already set up, please proceed directly to step 1.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have an Azure AD tenant, you can find [instructions on how to get one here](active-directory-howto-tenant.md).
trans-unit.target: If you don't have an Azure AD tenant, you can find [instructions on how to get one here](active-directory-howto-tenant.md).

trans-unit.source: If you don't have Apache Cordova set up on your machine, please install the following:
trans-unit.target: If you don't have Apache Cordova set up on your machine, please install the following:

trans-unit.source: Git
trans-unit.target: Git

trans-unit.source: NodeJS
trans-unit.target: NodeJS

trans-unit.source: [Cordova CLI](https://cordova.apache.org/)
trans-unit.target: [Cordova CLI](https://cordova.apache.org/)

trans-unit.source: (can be easily installed via NPM package manager: `npm install -g cordova`)
trans-unit.target: (can be easily installed via NPM package manager: `npm install -g cordova`)

trans-unit.source: Note that those should work both on the PC and on the Mac.
trans-unit.target: Note that those should work both on the PC and on the Mac.

trans-unit.source: Each target platform has different prerequisites.
trans-unit.target: Each target platform has different prerequisites.

trans-unit.source: To build and run Windows Tablet/PC or Phone app version
trans-unit.target: To build and run Windows Tablet/PC or Phone app version

trans-unit.source: [Visual Studio 2013 for Windows with Update 2 or later](http://www.visualstudio.com/downloads/download-visual-studio-vs#d-express-windows-8) (Express or another version).
trans-unit.target: [Visual Studio 2013 for Windows with Update 2 or later](http://www.visualstudio.com/downloads/download-visual-studio-vs#d-express-windows-8) (Express or another version).

trans-unit.source: To build and run for iOS
trans-unit.target: To build and run for iOS

trans-unit.source: Xcode 5.x or greater.
trans-unit.target: Xcode 5.x or greater.

trans-unit.source: Download it at http://developer.apple.com/downloads or the [Mac App Store](http://itunes.apple.com/us/app/xcode/id497799835?mt=12)
trans-unit.target: Download it at http://developer.apple.com/downloads or the [Mac App Store](http://itunes.apple.com/us/app/xcode/id497799835?mt=12)

trans-unit.source: [ios-sim](https://www.npmjs.org/package/ios-sim) – allows you to launch iOS apps into the iOS Simulator from the command line (can be easily installed via the terminal: `npm install -g ios-sim`)
trans-unit.target: [ios-sim](https://www.npmjs.org/package/ios-sim) – allows you to launch iOS apps into the iOS Simulator from the command line (can be easily installed via the terminal: `npm install -g ios-sim`)

trans-unit.source: To build and run application for Android
trans-unit.target: To build and run application for Android

trans-unit.source: Install [Java Development Kit (JDK) 7](http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/downloads/jdk7-downloads-1880260.html) or later.
trans-unit.target: Install [Java Development Kit (JDK) 7](http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/downloads/jdk7-downloads-1880260.html) or later.

trans-unit.source: Make sure `JAVA_HOME` (Environment Variable) is correctly set according to JDK installation path (for example C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.7.0_75).
trans-unit.target: Make sure `JAVA_HOME` (Environment Variable) is correctly set according to JDK installation path (for example C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.7.0_75).

trans-unit.source: Install [Android SDK](http://developer.android.com/sdk/installing/index.html?pkg=tools) and add `<android-sdk-location>\tools` location (for example, C:\tools\Android\android-sdk\tools) to your `PATH` Environment Variable.
trans-unit.target: Install [Android SDK](http://developer.android.com/sdk/installing/index.html?pkg=tools) and add `<android-sdk-location>\tools` location (for example, C:\tools\Android\android-sdk\tools) to your `PATH` Environment Variable.

trans-unit.source: Open Android SDK Manager (for example, via terminal: `android`) and install
trans-unit.target: Open Android SDK Manager (for example, via terminal: `android`) and install

trans-unit.source: *Android 5.0.1 (API 21)* platform SDK
trans-unit.target: *Android 5.0.1 (API 21)* platform SDK

trans-unit.source: *Android SDK Build-tools* version 19.1.0 or higher
trans-unit.target: *Android SDK Build-tools* version 19.1.0 or higher

trans-unit.source: *Android Support Repository* (Extras)
trans-unit.target: *Android Support Repository* (Extras)

trans-unit.source: Android sdk doesn't provide any default emulator instance.
trans-unit.target: Android sdk doesn't provide any default emulator instance.

trans-unit.source: Create a new one by running `android avd` from terminal and then selecting *Create...* if you want to run Android app on emulator.
trans-unit.target: Create a new one by running `android avd` from terminal and then selecting *Create...* if you want to run Android app on emulator.

trans-unit.source: Recommended *Api Level* is 19 or higher, see [AVD Manager] (http://developer.android.com/tools/help/avd-manager.html) for more information about Android emulator and creation options.
trans-unit.target: Recommended *Api Level* is 19 or higher, see [AVD Manager] (http://developer.android.com/tools/help/avd-manager.html) for more information about Android emulator and creation options.

trans-unit.source: 1. Register an application with Azure AD
trans-unit.target: 1. Register an application with Azure AD

trans-unit.source: Note: this step is optional.
trans-unit.target: Note: this step is optional.

trans-unit.source: The tutorial provided pre-provisioned values that will allow you to see the sample in action without doing any provisioning in your own tenant.
trans-unit.target: The tutorial provided pre-provisioned values that will allow you to see the sample in action without doing any provisioning in your own tenant.

trans-unit.source: However it is recommended that you do perform this step and become familiar with the process, as it will be required when you will create your own applications.
trans-unit.target: However it is recommended that you do perform this step and become familiar with the process, as it will be required when you will create your own applications.

trans-unit.source: Azure AD will only issue tokens to known applications.
trans-unit.target: Azure AD will only issue tokens to known applications.

trans-unit.source: Before you can use Azure AD from your app, you need to create an entry for it in your tenant.
trans-unit.target: Before you can use Azure AD from your app, you need to create an entry for it in your tenant.

trans-unit.source: To register a new application in your tenant,
trans-unit.target: To register a new application in your tenant,

trans-unit.source: Sign into the Azure Management Portal
trans-unit.target: Sign into the Azure Management Portal

trans-unit.source: In the left hand nav, click on Active Directory
trans-unit.target: In the left hand nav, click on Active Directory

trans-unit.source: Select the tenant where you wish to register the application
trans-unit.target: Select the tenant where you wish to register the application

trans-unit.source: Click the Applications tab, and click add in the bottom drawer.
trans-unit.target: Click the Applications tab, and click add in the bottom drawer.

trans-unit.source: Follow the prompts and create a new “Native Client Application”
trans-unit.target: Follow the prompts and create a new “Native Client Application”

trans-unit.source: The name of the application will describe your application to end-users
trans-unit.target: The name of the application will describe your application to end-users

trans-unit.source: The “Redirect URI” is the URI used to return tokens to your app.
trans-unit.target: The “Redirect URI” is the URI used to return tokens to your app.

trans-unit.source: Enter `http://MyDirectorySearcherApp`.
trans-unit.target: Enter `http://MyDirectorySearcherApp`.

trans-unit.source: Once you’ve completed registration, AAD will assign your app a unique client identifier.
trans-unit.target: Once you’ve completed registration, AAD will assign your app a unique client identifier.

trans-unit.source: You’ll need this value in the next sections: you can find it in the Configure tab of the newly created app.
trans-unit.target: You’ll need this value in the next sections: you can find it in the Configure tab of the newly created app.

trans-unit.source: 2. Clone the repositories required for the tutorial
trans-unit.target: 2. Clone the repositories required for the tutorial

trans-unit.source: From your shell or command line, type the following command:
trans-unit.target: From your shell or command line, type the following command:

trans-unit.source: 3. Create the Cordova app
trans-unit.target: 3. Create the Cordova app

trans-unit.source: There are multiple ways of creating Cordova applications.
trans-unit.target: There are multiple ways of creating Cordova applications.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial we will use the Cordova command line interface (CLI).
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial we will use the Cordova command line interface (CLI).

trans-unit.source: From your shell or command line, type the following command:
trans-unit.target: From your shell or command line, type the following command:

trans-unit.source: That will create the folder structure and scaffolding for the Cordova project, copying the content of the starter project in the www subfolder.
trans-unit.target: That will create the folder structure and scaffolding for the Cordova project, copying the content of the starter project in the www subfolder.

trans-unit.source: Move to the new DirSearchClient folder.
trans-unit.target: Move to the new DirSearchClient folder.

trans-unit.source: Add the whitelist plugin, necessary for invoking the Graph API.
trans-unit.target: Add the whitelist plugin, necessary for invoking the Graph API.

trans-unit.source: Next, add all of the platforms you want to support.
trans-unit.target: Next, add all of the platforms you want to support.

trans-unit.source: In order to have a working sample, you will need to execute at least one of the commands below.
trans-unit.target: In order to have a working sample, you will need to execute at least one of the commands below.

trans-unit.source: Note that you will not be able to emulate iOS on Windows, or Windows/Windows Phone on a Mac.
trans-unit.target: Note that you will not be able to emulate iOS on Windows, or Windows/Windows Phone on a Mac.

trans-unit.source: Finally, you can add the ADAL for Cordova plugin to your project.
trans-unit.target: Finally, you can add the ADAL for Cordova plugin to your project.

trans-unit.source: 3. Add code to authenticate users and obtain tokens from AAD
trans-unit.target: 3. Add code to authenticate users and obtain tokens from AAD

trans-unit.source: The application you are developing in this tutorial will provide a bare-bone directory search feature, where the end user can type the alias of any user in the directory and visualize some basic attributes.
trans-unit.target: The application you are developing in this tutorial will provide a bare-bone directory search feature, where the end user can type the alias of any user in the directory and visualize some basic attributes.

trans-unit.source: The starter project contains the definition of the basic user interface of the app (in www/index.html) and the scaffolding that wires up basic app event cycles, user interface bindings and results display logic (in www/js/index.js).
trans-unit.target: The starter project contains the definition of the basic user interface of the app (in www/index.html) and the scaffolding that wires up basic app event cycles, user interface bindings and results display logic (in www/js/index.js).

trans-unit.source: The only thing left out for you is to add the logic implementing identity tasks.
trans-unit.target: The only thing left out for you is to add the logic implementing identity tasks.

trans-unit.source: The very first thing you need to do is to introduce in your code the protocol values that are used by AAD for identifying your app and the resources you target.
trans-unit.target: The very first thing you need to do is to introduce in your code the protocol values that are used by AAD for identifying your app and the resources you target.

trans-unit.source: Those values will be used to construct the token requests later on.
trans-unit.target: Those values will be used to construct the token requests later on.

trans-unit.source: Insert the snippet below at the very top of the index.js file.
trans-unit.target: Insert the snippet below at the very top of the index.js file.

trans-unit.source: The `redirectUri` and `clientId` values should match the values describing your app in AAD.
trans-unit.target: The `redirectUri` and `clientId` values should match the values describing your app in AAD.

trans-unit.source: You can find those from the Configure tab in the Azure portal, as described in step 1 earlier in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: You can find those from the Configure tab in the Azure portal, as described in step 1 earlier in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Note: if you opted for not registering a new app in your own tenant, you can simply paste the pre-configured values above as is - that will allow you to see the sample running, though you should always create your own entry for your apps meant for production.
trans-unit.target: Note: if you opted for not registering a new app in your own tenant, you can simply paste the pre-configured values above as is - that will allow you to see the sample running, though you should always create your own entry for your apps meant for production.

trans-unit.source: Next, we need to add the actual token request code.
trans-unit.target: Next, we need to add the actual token request code.

trans-unit.source: Insert the following snippet between the `search `and `renderdata `definitions.
trans-unit.target: Insert the following snippet between the `search `and `renderdata `definitions.

trans-unit.source: Let's examine that function by breaking it down in its two main parts.
trans-unit.target: Let's examine that function by breaking it down in its two main parts.

trans-unit.source: This sample is designed to work with any tenant, as opposed to be tied to a particular one.
trans-unit.target: This sample is designed to work with any tenant, as opposed to be tied to a particular one.

trans-unit.source: It uses the "/common" endpoint, which allows the user to enter any account at authentication time and directs the request to the tenant it belongs.
trans-unit.target: It uses the "/common" endpoint, which allows the user to enter any account at authentication time and directs the request to the tenant it belongs.

trans-unit.source: This first part of the method inspects the ADAL cache to see if there is already a stored token - and if there is, it uses the tenants it came from for re-initializing ADAL.
trans-unit.target: This first part of the method inspects the ADAL cache to see if there is already a stored token - and if there is, it uses the tenants it came from for re-initializing ADAL.

trans-unit.source: This is necessary to avoid extra prompts, as the use of "/common" always results in asking the user to enter a new account.
trans-unit.target: This is necessary to avoid extra prompts, as the use of "/common" always results in asking the user to enter a new account.

trans-unit.source: The second part of the method performs the proper tokewn request.
trans-unit.target: The second part of the method performs the proper tokewn request.

trans-unit.source: The `acquireTokenSilentAsync` method asks to ADAL to return a token for the specified resource without showing any UX.
trans-unit.target: The `acquireTokenSilentAsync` method asks to ADAL to return a token for the specified resource without showing any UX.

trans-unit.source: That can happen if the cache already has a suitable access token stored, or if there is a refresh token that can be used to get a new access token without shwoing any prompt.
trans-unit.target: That can happen if the cache already has a suitable access token stored, or if there is a refresh token that can be used to get a new access token without shwoing any prompt.

trans-unit.source: If that attempt fails, we fall back on `acquireTokenAsync` - which will visibly prompt the user to authenticate.
trans-unit.target: If that attempt fails, we fall back on `acquireTokenAsync` - which will visibly prompt the user to authenticate.

trans-unit.source: Now that we have the token, we can finally invoke the Graph API and perform the search query we want.
trans-unit.target: Now that we have the token, we can finally invoke the Graph API and perform the search query we want.

trans-unit.source: Insert the following snippet right below the `authenticate` definition.
trans-unit.target: Insert the following snippet right below the `authenticate` definition.

trans-unit.source: The starting point files supplied a barebone UX for entering a user's alias in a textbox.
trans-unit.target: The starting point files supplied a barebone UX for entering a user's alias in a textbox.

trans-unit.source: This method uses that value to construct a query, combine it with the access token, send it to the Graph, and parse the results.
trans-unit.target: This method uses that value to construct a query, combine it with the access token, send it to the Graph, and parse the results.

trans-unit.source: The renderData method, already present in the starting point file, takes care to visualize the results.
trans-unit.target: The renderData method, already present in the starting point file, takes care to visualize the results.

trans-unit.source: 4. Run
trans-unit.target: 4. Run

trans-unit.source: Your app is finally ready to run!
trans-unit.target: Your app is finally ready to run!

trans-unit.source: Operating it is very simple: once the app starts, enter in the text box the alias of the user you want to look up - then click the button.
trans-unit.target: Operating it is very simple: once the app starts, enter in the text box the alias of the user you want to look up - then click the button.

trans-unit.source: You will be prompted for authentication.
trans-unit.target: You will be prompted for authentication.

trans-unit.source: Upon successful authentication and successful search, the attributes of the searched user will be displayed.
trans-unit.target: Upon successful authentication and successful search, the attributes of the searched user will be displayed.

trans-unit.source: Subsequent runs will perform the search without showing any prompt, thanks to the presence in cache of the token previously acquired.
trans-unit.target: Subsequent runs will perform the search without showing any prompt, thanks to the presence in cache of the token previously acquired.

trans-unit.source: The concrete steps for running the app vary by platform.
trans-unit.target: The concrete steps for running the app vary by platform.

trans-unit.source: To build and run Windows Tablet/PC application version
trans-unit.target: To build and run Windows Tablet/PC application version

trans-unit.source: __Note__: During first run you may be asked to sign in for a developer license.
trans-unit.target: __Note__: During first run you may be asked to sign in for a developer license.

trans-unit.source: See [Developer license]( https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/hh974578.aspx) for more details.
trans-unit.target: See [Developer license]( https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/hh974578.aspx) for more details.

trans-unit.source: To build and run application on Windows Phone 8.1
trans-unit.target: To build and run application on Windows Phone 8.1

trans-unit.source: To run on connected device: `cordova run windows --device -- --phone`
trans-unit.target: To run on connected device: `cordova run windows --device -- --phone`

trans-unit.source: To run on default emulator: `cordova emulate windows -- --phone`
trans-unit.target: To run on default emulator: `cordova emulate windows -- --phone`

trans-unit.source: Use `cordova run windows --list -- --phone` to see all available targets and `cordova run windows --target=<target_name> -- --phone` to run application on specific device or emulator (for example, `cordova run windows --target="Emulator 8.1 720P 4.7 inch" -- --phone`).
trans-unit.target: Use `cordova run windows --list -- --phone` to see all available targets and `cordova run windows --target=<target_name> -- --phone` to run application on specific device or emulator (for example, `cordova run windows --target="Emulator 8.1 720P 4.7 inch" -- --phone`).

trans-unit.source: To build and run on Android device
trans-unit.target: To build and run on Android device

trans-unit.source: To run on connected device: `cordova run android --device`
trans-unit.target: To run on connected device: `cordova run android --device`

trans-unit.source: To run on default emulator: `cordova emulate android`
trans-unit.target: To run on default emulator: `cordova emulate android`

trans-unit.source: __Note__: Make sure you've created emulator instance using *AVD Manager* as it is showed in *Prerequisites* section.
trans-unit.target: __Note__: Make sure you've created emulator instance using *AVD Manager* as it is showed in *Prerequisites* section.

trans-unit.source: Use `cordova run android --list` to see all available targets and `cordova run android --target=<target_name>` to run application on specific device or emulator (for example, `cordova run android --target="Nexus4_emulator"`).
trans-unit.target: Use `cordova run android --list` to see all available targets and `cordova run android --target=<target_name>` to run application on specific device or emulator (for example, `cordova run android --target="Nexus4_emulator"`).

trans-unit.source: To build and run on iOS device
trans-unit.target: To build and run on iOS device

trans-unit.source: To run on connected device: `cordova run ios --device`
trans-unit.target: To run on connected device: `cordova run ios --device`

trans-unit.source: To run on default emulator: `cordova emulate ios`
trans-unit.target: To run on default emulator: `cordova emulate ios`

trans-unit.source: __Note__: Make sure you have `ios-sim` package installed to run on emulator.
trans-unit.target: __Note__: Make sure you have `ios-sim` package installed to run on emulator.

trans-unit.source: See *Prerequisites* section for more details.
trans-unit.target: See *Prerequisites* section for more details.

trans-unit.source: Use `cordova run --help` to see additional build and run options.
trans-unit.target: Use `cordova run --help` to see additional build and run options.

trans-unit.source: For reference, the completed sample (without your configuration values) is provided here.
trans-unit.target: For reference, the completed sample (without your configuration values) is provided here.

trans-unit.source: You can now move on to more advanced (ok, and more interesting) scenarios.
trans-unit.target: You can now move on to more advanced (ok, and more interesting) scenarios.

trans-unit.source: You may want to try:
trans-unit.target: You may want to try:

trans-unit.source: Secure a Node.js Web API with Azure AD >>
trans-unit.target: Secure a Node.js Web API with Azure AD >>

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
